content.title: Raynaud Phenomenon
content.definition: Raynaud phenomenon is episodic, reversible digital vasospasm triggered by cold or emotional stress, characterized by well-demarcated color changes in digits progressing through white (pallor), blue (cyanosis), and red (rubor) phases.

secondary_raynaud.characteristics: Associated with underlying disease or external cause
secondary_raynaud.prognosis: May cause digital ulcers, tissue loss

triphasic_color_change.note: Not all patients show all 3 phases

pathophysiology.structural: Fixed vascular changes in secondary forms

diagnosis.clinical: History of episodic color changes with cold exposure
diagnosis.nailfold_capillaroscopy: Normal in primary, abnormal in secondary (scleroderma pattern)
diagnosis.laboratory: ANA, anti-centromere, anti-Scl-70, ESR if secondary suspected

treatment.behavioral: Avoid cold, wear gloves, smoking cessation, avoid triggering medications
treatment.surgical: Sympathectomy (digital or thoracic) for refractory cases
treatment.for_ulcers: Aggressive wound care, debridement, consider amputation if necrotic

explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Raynaud Phenomenon.

learning_objectives: Distinguish primary from secondary Raynaud phenomenon
Describe triphasic color changes and pathophysiology
Identify red flags suggesting secondary Raynaud
Outline treatment algorithm from behavioral to surgical
clinical_pearls: Nailfold capillaroscopy distinguishes primary from secondary
Digital ulcers should always prompt workup for secondary causes
Scleroderma is the most common connective tissue disease associated
Calcium channel blockers are first-line pharmacotherapy
pedagogical.board_yield: HIGH - important for differential diagnosis of digital ischemia
